Basal Cell Carcinoma.cause: Most common form of skin cancer, often linked to long-term exposure to UV radiation (sun/tanning beds).
Basal Cell Carcinoma.remedy: Requires surgical excision (Mohs surgery) as the definitive cure. No topical home remedy is effective.
Basal Cell Carcinoma.usage: Consult a dermatologist immediately for biopsy and treatment planning. Early detection is key.
Basal Cell Carcinoma.note: BCC rarely metastasizes but can cause local tissue destruction if left untreated. It appears as a pearly nodule.
Basal Cell Carcinoma.ayurvedic_diagnosis: Can be correlated to Granthi (minor neoplasm) or Arbuda (malignant neoplasm). Involves vitiation of all three Doshas (Tridoshaja Vyadhi), particularly Kapha and Rakta (blood tissue).

Darier_s Disease.cause: A rare genetic skin disorder caused by mutations in the ATP2A2 gene, leading to abnormal keratinization.
Darier_s Disease.remedy: Topical retinoids and oral vitamin A derivatives (acitretin) help control keratin buildup.
Darier_s Disease.usage: Apply topical retinoids under dermatological supervision once daily at night to affected areas.
Darier_s Disease.note: Avoid heat and sweating as they can worsen the condition. Maintain good hygiene and hydration.
Darier_s Disease.ayurvedic_diagnosis: Corresponds to a type of Kshudra Kushtha (minor skin disorder) involving predominant Pitta and Kapha Dosha vitiation, affecting Mamsa and Meda Dhatu (muscle and fat tissues) leading to abnormal cellular growth (keratinization).

Epidermolysis Bullosa Pruriginosa.cause: A rare inherited blistering skin disorder due to COL7A1 gene mutations affecting collagen.
Epidermolysis Bullosa Pruriginosa.remedy: Focuses on wound care, avoiding trauma, and using topical corticosteroids or tacrolimus.
Epidermolysis Bullosa Pruriginosa.usage: Apply mild topical corticosteroid to pruritic nodules twice daily and keep skin protected with dressings.
Epidermolysis Bullosa Pruriginosa.note: Genetic counseling is advised. Avoid scratching to prevent infection and scarring.
Epidermolysis Bullosa Pruriginosa.ayurvedic_diagnosis: This is a Vata-Pitta Pradhana Vyadhi (Vata and Pitta dominant disorder). Vata causes the fragility (Tvaka Bheda) and itching (Kandu), while Pitta causes heat and inflammation, leading to blistering (Sphota).

Hailey-Hailey Disease.cause: Genetic disorder due to ATP2C1 mutation causing skin fragility and recurrent erosions.
Hailey-Hailey Disease.remedy: Topical corticosteroids or tacrolimus ointment to control inflammation.
Hailey-Hailey Disease.usage: Apply thin layer of corticosteroid cream to lesions twice daily until cleared.
Hailey-Hailey Disease.note: Avoid heat, friction, and sweating which trigger flare-ups. Maintain skin dryness.
Hailey-Hailey Disease.ayurvedic_diagnosis: Likely a Vata-Pitta disorder aggravated by heat and friction. Pitta causes burning and erosion (Daha, Vidahi), and Vata causes dryness and recurrent skin breakage (Rukshata, Tvaka Bheda).

Herpes Simplex.cause: Viral infection caused by Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV-1 or HSV-2).
Herpes Simplex.remedy: Antiviral creams (acyclovir) or oral antiviral medication for faster healing.
Herpes Simplex.usage: Apply acyclovir cream five times daily for 4–5 days at the first sign of outbreak.
Herpes Simplex.note: Highly contagious. Avoid direct skin contact during active lesions.
Herpes Simplex.ayurvedic_diagnosis: Can be categorized as a type of Visarpa or Kaksha. It is a Pitta-Rakta Pradhana Vyadhi (Pitta and blood-dominant) characterized by burning, redness, and small blisters (Sphota). Recurrence is due to residual Dosha in the tissues.

Impetigo.cause: Bacterial infection by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes.
Impetigo.remedy: Topical antibiotic ointment (mupirocin) or oral antibiotics for widespread infection.
Impetigo.usage: Apply mupirocin ointment 3 times daily for 5–7 days. Keep the area clean.
Impetigo.note: Very contagious. Wash hands frequently and avoid sharing towels.
Impetigo.ayurvedic_diagnosis: A Kapha-Pitta disorder (Pus-forming). The characteristic weeping, honey-crusted lesions align with Pitta (inflammation, pus) and Kapha (fluid, stickiness) vitiation in the skin (Twak) and blood (Rakta).

Larva Migrans.cause: Skin infestation caused by hookworm larvae penetrating the skin, commonly from contaminated soil.
Larva Migrans.remedy: Oral anti-parasitic medication such as albendazole or ivermectin.
Larva Migrans.usage: Take prescribed oral antiparasitic for 3–5 days as directed by a physician.
Larva Migrans.note: Avoid walking barefoot on beaches or soil contaminated with animal feces.
Larva Migrans.ayurvedic_diagnosis: A condition caused by external organisms (Krimi Roga). The intense itching (Kandu) and migrating rash pattern are primarily driven by aggravated Vata and secondary Kapha vitiation, blocking channels (Srotas) beneath the skin.

Leprosy Borderline.cause: Chronic bacterial infection by Mycobacterium leprae affecting skin and nerves.
Leprosy Borderline.remedy: Multidrug therapy (MDT) combining dapsone, rifampicin, and clofazimine.
Leprosy Borderline.usage: Follow WHO-recommended MDT regimen under supervision for 12 months.
Leprosy Borderline.note: Early treatment prevents disability and transmission.
Leprosy Borderline.ayurvedic_diagnosis: A type of Mahakushtha (major skin disease). It is a Tridoshaja condition (involving all three doshas) affecting the deep tissues (Dhatus), specifically Rasa, Rakta, Mamsa, Meda, Asthi, Majja and Shukra.

Leprosy Lepromatous.cause: Severe form of leprosy with high bacterial load due to weak immune response.
Leprosy Lepromatous.remedy: Multidrug therapy with dapsone, rifampicin, and clofazimine.
Leprosy Lepromatous.usage: Adhere to long-term MDT protocol under medical supervision.
Leprosy Lepromatous.note: Regular follow-up is essential to monitor nerve involvement and prevent deformities.
Leprosy Lepromatous.ayurvedic_diagnosis: A severe Kapha-Vata dominance in Mahakushtha. Kapha causes thick lesions and nodules (Granthi), while Vata causes nerve damage (Nadivrana), loss of sensation, and pain.

Leprosy Tuberculoid.cause: Localized form of leprosy with few lesions due to strong immune response.
Leprosy Tuberculoid.remedy: Multidrug therapy (MDT) for 6 months using rifampicin and dapsone.
Leprosy Tuberculoid.usage: Follow supervised therapy as per WHO guidelines.
Leprosy Tuberculoid.note: Early diagnosis prevents nerve damage and spread.
Leprosy Tuberculoid.ayurvedic_diagnosis: A localized, less severe Kapha-Vata type of Kushtha with distinct patches and marked anesthesia (Sparsha Hani - loss of sensation). Strong immune response limits the spread of Doshas.

Lichen Planus.cause: Inflammatory condition possibly due to immune response against skin cells.
Lichen Planus.remedy: Topical corticosteroids or oral antihistamines to reduce itching and inflammation.
Lichen Planus.usage: Apply corticosteroid cream twice daily for 2–4 weeks.
Lichen Planus.note: Avoid scratching to prevent skin thickening and pigmentation.
Lichen Planus.ayurvedic_diagnosis: Correlated with Vicharchika or Kitibha. Primarily a Pitta-Kapha disorder where Pitta causes inflammation and purple color (Raga), and Kapha causes the thick plaques and chronic itch (Kandu).

Lupus Erythematosus Chronicus Discoides.cause: Autoimmune condition where the immune system attacks skin cells causing chronic lesions.
Lupus Erythematosus Chronicus Discoides.usage: Apply topical corticosteroid to lesions twice daily. Use sunscreen regularly.
Lupus Erythematosus Chronicus Discoides.note: Avoid sunlight exposure which may trigger flare-ups.
Lupus Erythematosus Chronicus Discoides.ayurvedic_diagnosis: A Pitta-Rakta Pradhana Vyadhi (Pitta and blood-dominant) aggravated by heat (Sunlight). Pitta causes inflammation, redness, and erosion (Daha), leading to chronic scarring and permanent tissue changes.

Melanoma.cause: Malignant growth of melanocytes, primarily caused by UV radiation exposure.
Melanoma.remedy: Surgical removal and possible immunotherapy or chemotherapy.
Melanoma.usage: Seek immediate dermatological evaluation for biopsy and staging.
Melanoma.note: Early detection dramatically improves survival. Watch for changing moles.
Melanoma.ayurvedic_diagnosis: A form of Arbuda (malignant neoplasm). Involves severe, deep vitiation of all three Doshas affecting the Meda (fat) and Mamsa (muscle) Dhatus. The dark pigmentation is a sign of deep Rakta (blood tissue) and Pitta vitiation.

Molluscum Contagiosum.cause: Viral infection by Molluscum contagiosum virus (a poxvirus).
Molluscum Contagiosum.remedy: Lesions can be treated with cryotherapy, curettage, or topical acids.
Molluscum Contagiosum.usage: Apply topical salicylic acid or tretinoin cream daily as advised.
Molluscum Contagiosum.note: Usually self-limiting within months. Avoid scratching or shaving over lesions.
Molluscum Contagiosum.ayurvedic_diagnosis: A Kapha and Meda Dhatu disorder. The localized, painless, dome-shaped papules are indicative of Kapha dominance and obstruction of the channels (Srotas) in the fat tissue (Meda).

Mycosis Fungoides.cause: Rare cancer of T-lymphocytes that primarily affects the skin.
Mycosis Fungoides.remedy: Phototherapy or topical corticosteroids for mild cases; systemic therapy for advanced stages.
Mycosis Fungoides.usage: Undergo regular dermatologic monitoring and follow prescribed treatment plan.
Mycosis Fungoides.note: Chronic condition requiring long-term management by specialists.
Mycosis Fungoides.ayurvedic_diagnosis: Correlated with Granthi or a persistent form of Kushtha. A Tridoshaja condition with the development of abnormal tissue growth (Arbuda) in the skin (lymphocytes are affected), indicating involvement of Rasa and Rakta Dhatus.

Neurofibromatosis.cause: Genetic disorder causing benign nerve sheath tumors and café-au-lait spots.
Neurofibromatosis.remedy: No cure; treatment focuses on surgical removal of problematic growths.
Neurofibromatosis.usage: Regular monitoring for tumor growth or neurological symptoms.
Neurofibromatosis.note: Genetic counseling recommended for affected families.
Neurofibromatosis.ayurvedic_diagnosis: The fibrous nodules are a form of Granthi (benign tumor) primarily caused by aggravated Kapha and Meda Dhatu vitiation, leading to localized overgrowth. The nerve involvement is due to aggravated Vata.

Papilomatosis Confluentes And Reticulate.cause: Unclear cause; possibly linked to abnormal keratinization or bacterial infection.
Papilomatosis Confluentes And Reticulate.remedy: Oral minocycline or topical retinoids can be effective.
Papilomatosis Confluentes And Reticulate.usage: Take oral minocycline 100mg daily for 6 weeks under supervision.
Papilomatosis Confluentes And Reticulate.note: Recurrences are common; maintain good hygiene.
Papilomatosis Confluentes And Reticulate.ayurvedic_diagnosis: A Kapha Pradhana Vyadhi due to the warty/papillomatous nature (Kshudra Kushtha). The confluence and hyperpigmentation suggest involvement of Kapha (thickening) and Rakta (pigmentation).

Pediculosis Capitis.cause: Infestation by Pediculus humanus capitis (head louse).
Pediculosis Capitis.remedy: Topical permethrin 1% lotion or natural alternatives like neem oil.
Pediculosis Capitis.usage: Apply lotion to scalp for 10 minutes, rinse, and repeat after 7 days.
Pediculosis Capitis.note: Wash bedding and combs to prevent re-infestation.
Pediculosis Capitis.ayurvedic_diagnosis: A Krimi Roga (parasitic condition) in the scalp. The severe itching (Kandu) is due to the activation of Vata and Kapha Dosha by the parasites. Treatment focuses on local application to destroy the organisms.

Pityriasis Rosea.cause: Possibly viral; exact cause unknown, often self-limiting.
Pityriasis Rosea.remedy: Moisturizers and antihistamines for itch relief.
Pityriasis Rosea.usage: Apply calamine lotion or hydrocortisone cream twice daily.
Pityriasis Rosea.note: Usually resolves in 6–8 weeks without treatment.
Pityriasis Rosea.ayurvedic_diagnosis: Correlated with a type of Visarpa or Kshudra Kushtha. Predominantly a Pitta-Rakta disorder causing redness and scaly patches. It often resolves spontaneously due to the body’s own defense mechanisms, indicating a superficial Dosha involvement.

Porokeratosis Actinic.cause: Abnormal keratinization process triggered by UV exposure.
Porokeratosis Actinic.usage: Apply thin layer to affected areas once daily for several weeks.
Porokeratosis Actinic.note: Monitor for malignant transformation in chronic cases.
Porokeratosis Actinic.ayurvedic_diagnosis: A Vata-Kapha dominance leading to abnormal keratinization (Kshudra Kushtha). Sun exposure ignites Pitta and increases the dryness (Vata) and abnormal growth (Kapha).

Psoriasis.cause: Autoimmune disorder causing rapid skin cell turnover leading to scaly plaques.
Psoriasis.remedy: Topical corticosteroids, vitamin D analogs, or phototherapy.
Psoriasis.usage: Apply medicated ointment twice daily and keep skin moisturized.
Psoriasis.note: Stress, infection, and cold weather can trigger flare-ups.
Psoriasis.ayurvedic_diagnosis: Corresponds to Kitibha Kushtha or Ekakushtha. A Kapha-Vata disorder where Vata causes dryness and scales (Rukshata, Daruna) and Kapha causes thickening and itching (Kandu). Blood (Rakta) is also vitiated.

Tinea Corporis.cause: Fungal infection (dermatophytes) spread by direct contact.
Tinea Corporis.remedy: Topical antifungal creams such as clotrimazole or terbinafine.
Tinea Corporis.usage: Apply antifungal twice daily for 2–4 weeks. Keep area dry.
Tinea Corporis.note: Avoid sharing towels or clothing. Seek oral antifungals if persistent.
Tinea Corporis.ayurvedic_diagnosis: Known as Dadru in Ayurveda. It is a Kapha-Pitta disorder, where Kapha causes the itching and elevation, and Pitta causes the redness and burning sensation, leading to a circular, inflamed rash.

Tinea Nigra.cause: Caused by Hortaea werneckii fungus infecting stratum corneum.
Tinea Nigra.usage: Apply antifungal twice daily for 2 weeks until discoloration clears.
Tinea Nigra.ayurvedic_diagnosis: A Kshudra Kushtha with a strong component of Rakta (blood/pigmentation) and Kapha vitiation, leading to blackish, non-inflammatory patches on the skin.

Tungiasis.cause: Infestation by Tunga penetrans (sand flea) burrowing into the skin.
Tungiasis.remedy: Careful extraction and topical antibiotic application.
Tungiasis.usage: Seek medical removal; apply antiseptic daily post-extraction.
Tungiasis.note: Wear footwear in endemic areas to prevent reinfection.
Tungiasis.ayurvedic_diagnosis: Another form of Krimi Roga causing localized inflammation. The burrowing causes pain and inflammation (Pitta-Vata), and subsequent swelling is due to Kapha accumulation in the affected area.

actinic keratosis.cause: Precancerous skin lesion due to long-term UV radiation exposure.
actinic keratosis.remedy: Cryotherapy or topical 5-fluorouracil under medical supervision.
actinic keratosis.usage: Apply 5-FU cream as prescribed for 2–4 weeks.
actinic keratosis.note: Monitor for progression to squamous cell carcinoma.
actinic keratosis.ayurvedic_diagnosis: A Vata-Kapha disorder (dry, rough growth) exacerbated by Pitta (heat/sun exposure). It can progress to a more severe Arbuda if the vitiation of Doshas and Dhatus deepens.

dermatofibroma.cause: Reactive process following minor skin injury or insect bite.
dermatofibroma.remedy: Usually requires no treatment; excision for cosmetic reasons.
dermatofibroma.usage: If irritated, apply mild corticosteroid cream for relief.
dermatofibroma.note: Firm, dimpled lesion — benign and stable.
dermatofibroma.ayurvedic_diagnosis: A type of Granthi (nodule) caused by localized Kapha and Meda vitiation and accumulation, often triggered by trauma (Vata). It is benign and stable due to low Pitta involvement.

nevus.cause: Clustered melanocytes causing pigmented skin spots.
nevus.remedy: No treatment needed unless suspicious changes occur.
nevus.usage: Regularly monitor for asymmetry or color change.
nevus.note: Seek evaluation for evolving or irregular moles.
nevus.ayurvedic_diagnosis: A benign pigmented lesion (Tilak Kala). The black/dark spots indicate a stable vitiation of Rakta Dhatu (blood/pigmentation) under the influence of Pitta and Kapha.

pigmented benign keratosis.cause: Noncancerous growth due to aging or sun exposure.
pigmented benign keratosis.remedy: Cryotherapy or laser removal for cosmetic purposes.
pigmented benign keratosis.usage: Consult dermatologist for removal if symptomatic.
pigmented benign keratosis.note: Distinguish from melanoma by dermoscopic examination.
pigmented benign keratosis.ayurvedic_diagnosis: A benign, stable growth consistent with Kapha dominance and Rakta vitiation leading to localized hyperpigmentation and thickening (Kshudra Kushtha).

seborrheic keratosis.cause: Waxy, non-cancerous growths common in older adults due to genetics and age.
seborrheic keratosis.remedy: Apply diluted Apple Cider Vinegar (folk remedy) or opt for cryotherapy.
seborrheic keratosis.usage: Apply 1:1 ACV-water mix twice daily for 7–10 days if mild.
seborrheic keratosis.note: If irritation or color change occurs, seek professional removal.
seborrheic keratosis.ayurvedic_diagnosis: A benign, age-related Kapha accumulation in the superficial tissues (Twak and Rasa Dhatus), leading to waxy, elevated growths (Kshudra Kushtha).

squamous cell carcinoma.cause: Malignant tumor due to prolonged UV exposure or chronic wounds.
squamous cell carcinoma.remedy: Surgical excision or cryotherapy for localized lesions.
squamous cell carcinoma.usage: Prompt dermatologic evaluation and removal required.
squamous cell carcinoma.note: Can metastasize if untreated. Use sunscreen regularly.
squamous cell carcinoma.ayurvedic_diagnosis: A form of Arbuda (malignant neoplasm). Primarily Pitta and Rakta vitiation causing ulceration and bleeding, combined with Kapha which causes the growth and hardness.

vascular lesion.cause: Abnormal proliferation of blood vessels in the skin.
vascular lesion.remedy: Laser therapy or observation depending on severity.
vascular lesion.usage: Seek dermatologic advice for cosmetic or functional concerns.
vascular lesion.note: Usually benign and may regress over time.
vascular lesion.ayurvedic_diagnosis: A Rakta Dhatu (blood tissue) and Pitta disorder, causing the proliferation of blood vessels (Rakta Gulma or Raktaja Granthi). Pitta is responsible for the red/purplish color.
